Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of bald man or child wearing headdress (now lost). Head only. Mould-made and hollow. Traces of white (gypsum?) coating with pink paint on areas of skin. Red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably made in Naukratis. Gutch dated this piece to between 150BC and 250AD (Hogarth 1899, Pl.12, no.231). Two grotesques from Dresden have been dated to the late 3rd century BC (Fischer, 1994, nos 422-3). However a similar treatment and facial expressions was found on a piece dated to the Roman period (Török 1995, pl.137, no. 256). Fischer, J. 1994, Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber, Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen, Tübinger Studien zur Archäologie und Kunstgeschichte 14, Tübingen. Török, L. 1995. Hellenistic and Roman terracottas from Egypt. Roma.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.565) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 94, no. 231, pl. 12, no. 231)
